Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.3.Eg.598 - Caribbean Montane Humid Forest EN (VU -- CR)'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.3.Eg.598 - Caribbean Montane Humid Forest EN (VU -- CR)'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.3.Eg.598 - Caribbean Montane Humid Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.3.Eg Caribbeo-Mesoamerican Montane Humid Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Characteristic-biota.Taxon: Prestoea acuminata var. montana (= Prestoea montana)

Abiotic-environment.Summary: Precipitación media anual >1600 mm, con frecuencia o estacionalmente rodeado por las nubes. 6.- Estación seca de 3- 5 meses. Suelos saturados de agua. 1.- Suelos ferralíticos ácidas pobres de las zonas serpentina de las montañas de cristal y Moa del este de Cuba y el oeste de Puerto Rico. 2.- Suelos ferralíticos amarillentos o rojas o franco-arcillosos derivados de calizas. 4.- El suelo puede ser volcánico, sedimentario y sustratos aluviales. Sureste de Cuba: suelos amarillos ácidos derivados de areniscas y tobas andesíticas; Cordillera Central de La Español suelos arcillosos ácidos.

Biotic-processes.Summary: Generalmente Bosques nublados entre 700 y 1600 metros de altitud., árboles retorcidos con menos de 7m de altura, alta densidad de tallos y área 1.- Entre los 400 y 900 m de altitud. Dosel abierto (15-22 m de altura). La mayoría de los árboles y arbustos son esclerófilo, con abundantes lianas pero baja densidad y diversidad de epífitas. 2.- . Por encima de los 800 m y hasta 1.600 m de altitud.Dosel cerrado o abierto, 15-25 m de altura, que consta de microfilos y notophylls.4.- Dosel confromado por dos capas. La capa superior conformado por Pinus maestrensis en Cuba, y por Pinus occidentalis en La Española. 5.- Por encima de 1600 m de altitud (en Puerto Rico > 700 m) pero puede presentarse a una menor altitud en zonas con alta precipitación. Stands tienen un dosel cerrado pero irregular (6-12 m de altura). El estrato arbustivo es casi impenetrable. Los helechos arborescentes y epífitas son abundantes. Suelo del bosque, troncos de árboles y ramas están cubiertas por las briofitas. 6.- Por encima de 2.200 m de altitu. Se caracterizado por un dosel abierto y monoespecíficas, con muchos arbustos endémicos y helechos en el sotobosque o un estrato herbáceo.

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: Bosque Abierto Húmedo Montano de Serpentinas del Caribe (1); Bosque Muy Húmedo Montano del Caribe (2); Bosque Húmedo Montano Mixto de Pino y Latifoliadas del Caribe (4); Bosque Enano Muy Húmedo Montano del Caribe (5); Bosque de Pino Montano y Alto Montano de la Isla Española (6) Montañas de las Islas del Caribe por encima de los 600- 700 m de altitud 1.- Cuba y Puerto Rico. 2.- Cuba, República Dominicana, Jamaica, Puerto Rico, y en algunas islas de Las Antillas Menores. 4.-Por encima de 2200 metros en la Cordillera Central de La Española. 5.- Cuba, República Dominicana, Jamaica, Las Antillas Menores y Puerto Rico. 6.- Isla Española
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'Trinidad and Tobago moist forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Assessment-unit.name: global

Ecosystem-subset.name: Global
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Regional or Continental-level assessment for the whole distribution of the '1.A.3.Eg.598 - Caribbean Montane Humid Forest' macrogroup.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for EN was reached for criteria. Uncertainty in the indicators suggests that the overall category can be in the range os VU -- CR.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of recent change in woodland cover reached the threshold for EN for subcriterion A1. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A1 could be in the range of LC -- EN.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of predicted future change in tree cover reached the threshold for VU for subcriterion A2b. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A2b could be in the range of EN -- VU.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of historical change in woodland cover reached the threshold for EN for subcriterion A3. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A3 could be in the range of VU -- CR.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Ecosystem-subset.name: National: Trinidad and Tobago

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for CR was reached for criteria.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of recent change in woodland cover reached the threshold for CR for subcriterion A1.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: This subcriterion was evaluated, but the uncertainty in the estimates of predicted future changes in tree cover was too high to reliable assign a category.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of historical change in woodland cover reached the threshold for CR for subcriterion A3.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.3.Eg.600 - Mesoamerican Montane Humid Forest NE'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.3.Eg.600 - Mesoamerican Montane Humid Forest NE'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.3.Eg.600 - Mesoamerican Montane Humid Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.3.Eg Caribbeo-Mesoamerican Montane Humid Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Abiotic-environment.Summary: la precipitación media anual: 2000-4000mm,alta humedad relativa anual> 90%, con una media de temperatura anual: 6-22C. La temperatura media anual es de 13-14◦C (hasta 18◦C en las partes inferiores del cinturón altitudinal), y la media de precipitación anual es de 1200 a 1500 mm (1). La precipitación anual es de más de 1500 mm y la temperatura media inferior a 18 °C (2). suelos profundos, bien drenados, se originó a partir de piedra caliza o rocas lo general ocurren enmetamórficas, a menudo afloran (1). Los suelos son poco profundos, pero con alto contenido de materia orgánica(2). Pendientes altas generalmente muy inclinadas, a veces rocosas. Suelos bien drenados y de textura variable.(3)

Biotic-processes.Summary: Forma de relieve variable (acantilado, cresta, cóncavo / convexo pendiente más altos bosques nublados a menudo se encuentran en la posición media ladera con pendiente moderada y suelos más profundos. Este tipo de bosque es uno de los ecosistemas que mejor expresan las condiciones de transición entre tropical y reinos biogeográficos templadas (1). Son fácilmente distinguibles de otros sistemas forestales por la abundancia de epífitas y la reducción en la densidad de trepadoras leñosas. Con el aumento de la elevación, la altura del dosel de los bosques nubosos es inferior a la de los bosques de tierras bajas; los árboles exhiben coronas compactas y troncos retorcidos; contrafuertes, lianas, palmas y hojas tienden a ser más pequeños, más gruesos y más duros, al parecer una adaptación a la transpiración suprimida debido a la alta humedad atmosférica (2). Generalmente los rodales puros se encuentran en pendientes que reciben poca precipitación y además experimentan quemas cada cierto tiempo. En estos casos el sotobosque es muy pobre y está dominado por especies de gramíneas (3)

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: Bsq. humedo montano y bsq.siempreverde nublado Sierra Madre Oriental de México al sur de Honduras y Nicaragua. México y Guatemala (1). Centro de México hasta el noreste de Argentina(2). Guatemala y Honduras (3)
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt pine-oak forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Sierra Madre del Sur pine-oak forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Sierra Madre de Oaxaca pine-oak forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Sierra Madre Oriental pine-oak forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Sierra Madre Occidental pine-oak forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Central American Atlantic moist forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Sierra Madre de Chiapas moist forests'
Global 200 ecoregion 'Sierra Madre Oriental and Occidental pine-oak forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.3.Eg.601 - Mesoamerican Pine-Oak Forest EN'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.3.Eg.601 - Mesoamerican Pine-Oak Forest EN'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.3.Eg.601 - Mesoamerican Pine-Oak Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.3.Eg Caribbeo-Mesoamerican Montane Humid Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Abiotic-environment.Summary: La temperatura media entre 12 °C y 20°C, con precipitación de 1500-3000 mm anuales, aunque generalmente más de 2000 mm y además con influencia de la neblina. (3) Suelos moderadamente profundos que a menudo son calcáreos y de textura franco arcillosa(1). Suelos volcánicos antiguos (2). suelos en general son ácidos, poco fértiles y sujetos a fuertes problemas de erosión si se transforma la cobertura vegetal. (3)

Biotic-processes.Summary: Pinos maderense y encinas entremezclados con matorrales irregulares en la mayoría de las laderas de altitud media (2300-2400 m elevación)(1). Este sistema agrupa los bosques nublados mixtos de montañas del norte de Centro América caracterizados por la asociación de especies de pino y encino (roble), y representa el límite de la influencia de la flora boreal en el Neotrópico caracterizada por una alta diversidad de coníferas.(3)

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: Bsq.de Pino Encino México, Guatemala, Honduras y el norte de Nicaragua. Sur de la Sierra Madre Occidental y Sur de America Central (1). Norte de Centro América (2). Sur de Chiapas, Mexico hasta el noroeste de Nicaragua, sobre la Sierra Madre de Chiapas, las montañas del sur de Guatemala, una importante porción en el centro de Honduras, norte del Salvador y el noroccidente de Nicaragua. (3)
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt pine-oak forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Sierra Madre del Sur pine-oak forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Sierra Madre de Oaxaca pine-oak forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Sierra Madre Occidental pine-oak forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Sierra Madre Oriental pine-oak forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Central American Atlantic moist forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Sierra Madre de Chiapas moist forests'
Global 200 ecoregion 'Sierra Madre Oriental and Occidental pine-oak forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Assessment-unit.name: global

Ecosystem-subset.name: Global
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Regional or Continental-level assessment for the whole distribution of the '1.A.3.Eg.601 - Mesoamerican Pine-Oak Forest' macrogroup.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for EN was reached for criterion.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of recent change in woodland cover reached the threshold for VU for subcriterion A1. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A1 could be in the range of LC -- EN.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of predicted future change in tree cover reached the threshold for EN for subcriterion A2b.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of historical change in woodland cover reached the threshold for VU for subcriterion A3. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A3 could be in the range of NT -- EN.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Ecosystem-subset.name: National: Honduras

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for EN was reached for criterion.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The recent changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A1. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A1 could be in the range of LC -- VU.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of predicted future change in tree cover reached the threshold for EN for subcriterion A2b.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The historical changes in woodland cover was near to the threshold for Vulnerable. For this reason it is considered Near Threatened under subcriterion A3. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A3 could be in the range of LC -- VU.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.3.Eg.602 - Southern Mesoamerican Montane Humid Forest VU'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.3.Eg.602 - Southern Mesoamerican Montane Humid Forest VU'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.3.Eg.602 - Southern Mesoamerican Montane Humid Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.3.Eg Caribbeo-Mesoamerican Montane Humid Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Abiotic-environment.Summary: La Cordillera de Talamanca en el sur de Centroamérica (1 y 2) suelos de origen volcánico, ricos en materia orgánica y generalmente con textura media y drenaje excesivo.(1 y 2)

Biotic-processes.Summary: Bosques de robles costarricenses son generalmente mono-o bi-específicos a nivel del dosel y albergan bambúes del género. Los bosques de robles costarricenses son extremadamente mixtos en el sentido de que se componen tanto de elementos tropicales como templados, donde robles holárticos ,alisos y conejos conviven con palmas tropicales, melastomataceas y tapires. Este sistema agrupa los bosques de roble montano bajos y húmedos, con palmas y helechos arborescentes en el sotobosque (1). Este sistema agrupa los bosques de roble sobre los 2500 m aproximadamente y hasta los 3100-3200 m snm. Estos bosques son muy húmedos y también tienen una estructura compleja y gran estatura, hacia su límite superior la estatura disminuye y los robles alternan principalmente con especies de Ericaceae (2)

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'Costa Rican seasonal moist forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.
